document.docAuthor: Fomichev, Alexander A. & Marusik, Yuri M.
document.masterDocTitle: A survey of East Palaearctic Gnaphosidae (Araneae). 11. New data on Gnaphosidae (Araneae) from Tajikistan

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A survey of East Palaearctic Gnaphosidae (Araneae). 11. New data on Gnaphosidae (Araneae) from Tajikistan

paragraph.treatmentCitationGroup:

, pl. 15, fig. 8 ( ♂ ).

Nomisia palaestina : Levy 1995: 938
, figs 48–52 ( ♂ ♀ ) —

, figs 19–20 ( ♀ );
Chatzaki 2010: 12
, figs 30–33 ( ♂ ♀ ).

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 14–21. Bulb (14–17) and epigyne (18–21) of
Nomisia palaestina
. 14–17 prolateral, ventral, retrolateral and apical; 18–19 ventral, intact; 20 ventral, macerated; 21 dorsal, macerated. Scale bars: 0.2 mm. Abbreviations: Em embolus, Fo fovea.

Diagnosis. The males of
N. palaestina
can be easily separated from all congeners by the large S-shaped embolus ( Em ). The females differ from others Central Asian species in having triangular epigynal fovea ( Fo ).

Type species:
Pythonissa variana C.L. Koch, 1839
from Germany .

Comments. This genus comprises 38 species and has almost worldwide distribution, being absent in North America, Northern Asia and Australia (WSC 2021). Only two species has been recorded from Central Asia.
